etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in George Low (1747–1795), naturalist. Probably from the unattested Norn reflex of the early Scandinavian word represented by Old Icelandic langvé (Icelandic langvía, langvígi, †langvé), Faroese lomvigi (goes to post-classical Latin lomwia), Norwegian †langivie, †lomgivie, †lomvifvie, †lomgive, †langve, †langvie, lomvie, (now usually) lomvi, early modern Danish †lomvibe from the Germanic base of long + a second element of uncertain and disputed origin, perhaps imitative of the bird's call
